title: Twenty-fifth Amendment to the US Constitution
anno: One day after the attack on the US capitol, there was interest in the constitutional amendment that addresses presidential succession and disability.

items.title: American politics
items.anno: American politics and politicians dominated many of the top articles in January, driven by the attack on the US capitol early in the month, and followed by the inauguration of Joe Biden as president weeks later.

items.title: Captain Tom
items.anno: The 100-year-old WWII veteran, who made international headlines in 2020 for raising over £30 million for the UK’s National Health Service, died in February.

items.title: American Civil War Widows
items.anno: Reddit can drive significant traffic to an article, as was the case in February with pages for American Civil War widows who survived into the 21st century, and Patrick Mahomes.

items.title: Dr. Seuss
items.anno: Dr. Seuss Enterprises announced it would stop publishing six Seuss books due to insensitive imagery, including And to Think That I Saw it on Mulberry Street and If I Ran the Zoo.

items.title: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex
items.anno: Oprah’s interview with the Duke and Duchess of Sussex brought royal controversy to US prime time and stoked public fascination with Meghan Markle.

items.title: Derek Chauvin
items.anno: The former Minneapolis police officer was found guilty on April 21 of killing George Floyd in 2020. He was later sentenced to 22.5 years in jail.

items.title: Bernie Madoff
items.anno: High-profile deaths drove traffic in April. These included actress Helen McCrory, rapper DMX, and Queen Elizabeth II’s husband, Prince Philip.

items.title: Halston
items.anno: Searches for historical figures David Berkowitz (the son of Sam) and fashion designer Halston were prompted by the release of related Netflix shows.

items.title: T. B. Joshua
items.anno: Nigerian pastor

items.title: UEFA Euro 2020
items.anno: TKT

items.title: Jeff Bezos
items.anno: Early in the month the billionaire stepped down as the CEO of Amazon, but he received more attention on July 20th when he flew to space on his Blue Origin New Shepard rocket.

items.title: 2020 Summer Olympics
items.anno: Held in Tokyo, Japan, the postponed 2020 Summer Olympics and its athletes dominated Wikipedia searches during the end of July.

items.title: Neeraj Chopra
items.anno: The track and field athlete is one of only two Indians to have won an individual Olympic gold medal, and the youngest-ever Indian Olympic gold medalist in an individual event.

items.title: Taliban
items.anno: The Taliban regained control of Afghanistan on August 15. By the end of the month, US troops left the country, ending their nearly 20-year mission there.

items.title: Emma Raducanu
items.anno: The British tennis player became the youngest athlete since Maria Sharapova at Wimbledon to win a Grand Slam title, beating out Leylah Fernandez to claim the US Open.

items.title: Squid Game
items.anno: The Korean-language thriller about contestants playing children’s games to pay off debt became one of Netflix’s most-watched programs.

items.title: Alec Baldwin
items.anno: A fatal shooting occurred on the set of the film Rust when actor Alec Baldwin was handling a prop gun.

items.title: Kenosha unrest shooting
items.anno: Following a two-week-long trial, 17-year-old Kyle Rittenhouse was found not guilty of shooting and killing two men during protests in Kenosha, Wisconsin.

items.title: Virgil Abloh
items.anno: The high-profile Ghanaian-American fashion designer died of Cancer in November, leaving a creative legacy that involved bridge-building across industries.

items.title: TKTK
items.anno: TKTK
